<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=15018>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
           Severity|major                       |minor
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CLOSED
         Resolution|---                         |NOT REPRODUCIBLE
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com

--- Comment #8 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
I could not reproduce this problem using R 4.5.1 (R.app). If someone can still
reproduce this on current version of R and macOS, feel free to re-open with
more details. Given we didn't get any similar report in the ~13 years, it may
be it was something very unusual, perhaps something not present on common
installations.

Without being able to reproduce this, we cannot make any progress on this
report.

If something like this was a problem I would have encountered on my system, I
would try to provide a minimal, reproducible example that makes that happen on
my system, something I could paste into R Console without further actions (only
then re-size the window manually). So I would e.g. try to reproduce with an R
loop printing lines of output (not a data frame, not something relying on
max.print).

It would not be surprising to see the performance of console window degrade if
the system was running out of memory, and that would not be necessarily a bug -
but, it is surprising one could reach such situation printing a data frame only
30 times when max.print is 100000. Certainly one cannot tell without being able
to reproduce the problem what is the bottleneck (e.g. whether glyph generation,
but then, why would there be a sharp cut-off point between slow and fast).

*[Bug 16226] install.packages option to install into user library when in non-interactive mode*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=16226>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
             Status|NEW                         |CLOSED
         Resolution|---                         |WISHLIST
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com

--- Comment #1 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
I think the lack of such option is deliberate, to increase the chances that the
user stays in control of the user home directory/personal library and is aware
when packages get installed there. After all, it is also the user who needs
eventually to clean up that library, e.g. when upgrading R. 

When programmatically installing packages, I would always use a separate
library for the given task, and do so regardless of whether the personal
library already exists or not.

<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18429>

Michael Chirico (<mailto:michaelchirico4@gmail.com|michaelchirico4@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |michaelchirico4@gmail.com

--- Comment #6 from Michael Chirico (<mailto:michaelchirico4@gmail.com|michaelchirico4@gmail.com>) ---
I rather agree with Martin about this being bad practice and would prefer not
to expose new surfaces where users can fall into a habit of using `"+"` when
they should be using `` `+` ``.

One extra piece of context -- I have a bit too much hard-earned experience here
of packages using text-as-code breaking "silently" because static analysis
tools are much worse at finding dependencies hidden in strings:

```
do.call("sd", ...)
# vs.
do.call(sd, ...)
```

`R CMD check` will find the `sd` if {stats} somehow falls off the search path,
but it won't find the `"sd"` -- we rely on unit testing to wind up with an
error from `"sd"` missing at run-time.

(using `"sd"` here to avoid bringing in non-default packages, but it could be
any non-{base} function that's not always guaranteed to be present).

Not directly related to this thread, but related to my contention with
functions-as-strings -- the same goes for formulas:

```
as.formula("y ~ foo::bar(x)")
# vs
y ~ foo::bar(x)
```

Static analysis is much better equipped to find the {foo} dependency in the
latter usage.

Obviously there's only so far static analysis can get you, but this is
something I've encountered enough times to come down on Martin's side of
avoiding functions-as-strings whenever possible.
